### Enhanced Information Summary

Chlorpropamide is a sulfonylurea class drug that is primarily used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus by increasing insulin secretion, which helps lower blood glucose levels. Unlike other sulfonylureas, chlorpropamide also has a unique property of enhancing the effect of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which can be beneficial in the treatment of diabetes insipidus, particularly the mild central form. This dual functionality makes chlorpropamide distinct among the options listed, as it can address both diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus.

The other drugs listed - Glibenclamide, Glicazide, and Glipizide - are also sulfonylureas that stimulate insulin release to control blood sugar in diabetes mellitus. However, they do not have an effect on ADH activity or the management of diabetes insipidus. This aligns with the medical consensus that these drugs are specifically effective for diabetes mellitus but not for diabetes insipidus.

The retrieved evidence paths, while broad, confirm the role of insulin in managing diabetes mellitus but do not provide additional specific insights into the treatment of diabetes insipidus with any of the drugs listed. Therefore, these paths do not alter the conclusion drawn from the medical consensus and the specific properties of chlorpropamide.

In conclusion, among the options provided, chlorpropamide is the only drug used to treat both diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus, leveraging its ability to increase insulin secretion and enhance ADH effect.
